title: 104_s771
content: Priority given to states for transfer of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense. Section 2547 of title 10, United States Code is amended to prioritize the transfer of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to states, local governments, Territories, or possessions before being used for humanitarian relief purposes. The President may also authorize the supplies for humanitarian use before being transferred to the mentioned entities. The amendment to Section 2547 of title 10, United States Code prioritizes the transfer of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to states, local governments, Territories, or possessions for emergency response purposes. The Secretary of Defense is granted authorities regarding the disposal of excess and surplus property. The National Defense Authorization Act is amended to exclude motor vehicles from support for counter drug activities. Two regional equipment centers are repealed. Additionally, transfers of property for environmental protection in foreign countries are addressed. SEC. 3 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 regarding transfers of property for environmental protection in foreign countries. No property can be transferred unless the Administrator of General Services determines there are no Federal or State use requirements under any other law. SEC. 4 amends the Small Business Act. SEC. 4 amends the Small Business Act to involve the Administrator of General Services and State agencies in surplus property distribution. SEC. 5 amends the Department of Energy Science Education Enhancement Act by reorganizing paragraphs. SEC. 6 amends the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to allow the delegation of authority to directors of Federal laboratories for the transfer and disposal of scientific surplus property to educational institutions or nonprofit organizations. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 allows directors of Federal laboratories to transfer scientific surplus property to educational institutions or nonprofit organizations for research and education purposes. The Administrator of General Services will review statutes on disposal and donation of surplus personal property and submit a report to Congress within 180 days. The report will assess program effectiveness, property administered in fiscal years 1993 and 1994, and make legislative recommendations for integrating and consolidating programs under a single Federal authority.
